question: I want to know about the plan to install smart traffic lights.
Will we have teleportation?
Will there be flying cars?
Will flying ever become a part of public transportation in the upcoming years?
Will there be more transportation to the seaport?
When are we going to have more electric car charging stations?
Will the sharing economy continue to revolutionize transportation?
When will they build the North/South Rail tunnel link?
Can we use the Charles River for shuttle services and transportation?
Will East Boston have a ferry?
When will downtown Boston be car-free?
Could we have insulated heat bubbles?
Will Boston be a leader in the movement towards solar roadways?
When will the Orange Line go to Roslindale?
Why does it take an hour to get from the North End to Southie?
What about electric scooters?  They're easy to park.  Get rid of cars.
How do we (really) account for the natural climate of New England?
Will Boston's transportation system be carbon neutral by 2030?
Will the T run between the seaport and Back Bay?
When will Boston get real BRT? We can do so much better than the Silver Line.
Will the city provide exclusive lanes for buses to improve speed and reliability?
I broke my leg last year and could not get on the bus. How will I get on the bus when I am old an in a wheelchair?
Are there going to be TVs on the trains?
How are we going to deal with too many cars and pollution?

How can Boston establish the impeccable transit infrastructure, like high speed rail connections to outer city areas/suburbs and modern subway systems with fast service and short wait times, that so many European cities achieved decades ago? (e.g. Paris, London, Berlin, Stockholm)
What are the plans for more parking?
Why couldn't satellite parking be built outside of Boston and VASTLY IMPROVED public transportation be built to connect the satellite centers with downtown Boston and Back Bay?
When will Boston impose a rush hour congestion charge (like London has done to wild success), to manage traffic via fundamental economic forces?
Will the city dedicate lanes to buses to improve capacity and reliability and speed?
Are the buses going to look different?
Won't mode share for cycling increase much faster if we built out the 2030 bicycle plan right away instead of waiting?
Why can' t the Charlie card with a Link pass on it finally be used on the commuter rail stops within the city of Boston or the Zone 1A stops?
What is stopping Boston from achieving a seamless, upgraded public transit system (like Paris did many years ago) where one can easily and quickly get from A to B without a car?

Why can't we lower Boston's default speed limit to 25mph?  Crash rates plummet at 25mph, and people hit by slower moving cars are far less injured/far more likely to survive.   A default speed limit of 25mph is good for everybody, including drivers.
Why is it consistently more reliable to drive to Boston than to take the MBTA?
Will the South train station and North train stations be connected?
Where are we going to put the new bus maintenance facilities so we can expand service in the core of the region?
How do we figure out who is responsible for clearing snow on sidewalks?
Who is going to cover the cost of reduced fares?
When will we start using pricing to manage street occupancy & turnover, instead of simply charging a static price set in the 1980s?

How will you ensure the solution is paid for into the future. Not a political toy, not like an embarrassing Yankee Swap gift that our govt doesn't know what to do with. This is a serious question; our roads, bridges, rail and other infrastructure are literally falling apart because funding is not secure and money was squandered on the Big Dig for years. Green transportation is good, it's right, but it has a cost. Don't backload it for the future. Thank you.

Why is the Northern Avenue Bridge no longer open to pedestrian traffic? It is an important link to the the Innovation District.  Being car-free, it is safe and comfortable for walking and biking.  Without it, I simply don't patronize businesses there anymore.
What can the city do to make buses go faster, especially in congested and well-used bus corridors like Blue Hill Ave, Mass Ave, Comm Ave, and Huntington/South Huntington?
Will Boston have a new bus system?
Will there be more public transit in and out of neighborhoods?
When will Hubway be available throughout all season in Boston??
With the gas tax indexing voted down and the sales tax reduced, how are we going to fund MBTA service expansion?
Marty, will you commute from Hopkinton to Boylston St. with @TeamWithAVision this April?  #BostonMarathon
What would it cost for the City to assume responsibility for sidewalk snow removal?
What if we got real time wait times for all transportation?
What if bicycles had their own separate paths and traffic lights?
When will the city invest in its public transportation system?
When will the city expand locations for parking motorcycles and other motorized 2-wheeled vehicles?
How can we in good conscience dream up system/service expansions when funding for infrastructure and equipment maintenance is woefully inadequate?
Will the only cars allowed within City limits be self-driving?
How much does it cost for the city to maintain a residential parking space? ...signage, towing/tickets/enforcement, snow clearing, street sweeping...
How will the City of Boston work with the MBTA to help move buses through the streets more efficiently?
How can we reduce or eliminate heavy vehicles (e.g. 18-wheelers) from Boston streets?

Will there ever be some sort of efficient transportation that connects the North Station and waterfront/Commercial Street neighborhoods to the South Station area?  The MBTA bus #6 was canceled after serving this route effectively for several years.  There is no efficient way to get from Commercial Street to South Station at 6:15 a.m., aside from walking. Yes, it is definitely a nice walk, but not in bad weather or if you're carrying a lot.  This just seems crazy given the increase in population along this route.

Whatever became of connecting North and South Stations?  I thought that was part of the Big Dig "mitigation."  It is complicated via T.  Light rail of some variety integrated into the Greenway somehow?  Thank you.

How can we reconcile transportation costs with incentives? If we factor in direct and indirect costs (environmental, social, opportunity) of each mode, how would that impact decision-making? How much could we give to lower-cost modes to encourage shifting?
Why not year-round Hubway?

How could it be this bad ?  Why does a major city like Boston need to borrow equipment from another state?  Why do we not already own this equipment?  Where has all the commuter revenue money gone?  Has it all been misspent while the MBTA has been so badly mismanaged?  The MBTA is the conduit for a flourishing and functional Boston.  How was it left in the hands of such incapable people?  This is truly a disgrace to a city and region filled with so many hard working people.  I actually hope we get the Olympics mainly so Boston is finally forced to update its archaic infrastructure (granted it will come at added local and federal cost, of course).  But that's what we have come to expect from our politically-driven government operations.  If the MBTA was a private company, they would have been bankrupt and replaced by a better industry option ages ago.  Shameful that it hasn't been.  You have lost our faith and trust.  Embarrassed yet again
ABC and Go Boston 2030 should be promoting this effort on the part of the MBTA Advisory Board to gather data on riders' end-to-end trip experiences: www.transitdiary.com
